Disturbances

DisturbanceSource class

class Sandbox_V1_4.DisturbanceSource(start_times: List[int] = [], stop_times: List[int] = [], enabled: bool = True)[source]

An abstract superclass for timed sources of disturbances. A DisturbanceSource is a subclass of System, which has no position.

Subclasses of DisturbanceSource must call its step() method using super().step(dt), so that disturbances are enabled and disabled at the right times.

When the DisturbanceSource is constructed, it is passed lists of times at which to be activated (enabled) and deactivated (disabled). A DisturbanceSource is disabled by default when first created. When a DisturbanceSource is active, the list of times to disable it is monitored, and when it is not active, the list of times to enable it is monitored. When the DistubanceSource’s internal clock, t, exceeds the first time in the currently monitored list, then the DisturbanceSource will be enabled/disabled as appropriate. When this happens, the listed time which has just been used will be removed from the list, so that the next time in the list (if there is one) will become the first element in the list.

As it is always the first elements in the two lists which are monitored, the two together must be ordered correctly with respect to time. For example, if start_times = [100, 200] and end_times = [50, 130], then the disturbance will be activated at t >= 100, and then deactivated in the next simulation step, as then t > 100 > 50. Then the same thing will happen again, at t >= 200 and in the following simulation step, because 200 > 130.

If no end_times are specified, then once any disturbance is active, it will be so until the simulation ends. If you have more start times than end times, and they are appropriately sequenced, then there will be a time at which the disturbance will be activated without ever being deactivated again. For example, if start_times = [100, 200, 500] and end_times = [150, 300], then the disturbance will be enabled and disabled twice, and then be enabled from t = 500 until the simulation ends (assuming that the simulation duration > 500).

If you would like a disturbance to be ‘one-shot’, i.e. only active for a single simulation step, then the easiest way to implement that is in the step() method of the subclass of DisturbanceSource, e.g. as in the SensoryInversionDisturbanceSource class step() method, where whenever the disturbance is applied, self.enabled is subsequently set to False to disable it again.

__init__(start_times: List[int] = [], stop_times: List[int] = [], enabled: bool = True)[source]
Parameters:

  • start_times – The list of times at which a DisturbanceSource is activated.

  • stop_times (list[int]) – The list of times at which a DisturbanceSource is deactivated.

  • enabled (bool) – A parameter which determines whether or not a DisturbanceSource is active. The DisturbanceSource manages this variable itself. In most cases, it will be best to leave this variable as False when a DisturbanceSource is constructed, and only use start_times and stop_times to inform the disturbance source when to change it.

reset() → None[source]

Reset DisturbanceSource by resetting its timer, enabled state and start/stop time lists.

step(dt: float) → None[source]

Step the disturbance source forwards in time. This is where the disturbance gets enabled and disabled. The effect of the disturbance is be implemented in the step methods for the subclasses of DisturbancSource

Parameters:

dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the disturbance source over.

MovingSensorsDisturbanceSource class

class Sandbox_V1_4.MovingSensorsDisturbanceSource(robot: Robot, max_move: float = 0.08726646259971647, move_left: float = True, move_right: float = True, start_times: List[int] = [], stop_times: List[int] = [], enabled: bool = True, sensor_indices: List[int] = [3, 4])[source]

A disturbance source class for making a Robot’s light sensors gradually change, through small random movements, their angular position on the robot’s body. The sensors will always be the body’s perimeter, and change their orientations to match their new angular positions.

__init__(robot, max_move=np.pi / 36, move_left=True, move_right=True, start_times=[], stop_times=[], enabled=True, sensor_indices=[3, 4])[source]
Parameters:

  • robot (class:Robot) – The class:Robot instance which will be disturbed.

  • max_move (float) – The maximum angle by which a sensor will move in a single simulation step.

  • move_left (bool) – Not used in this implementation.

  • move_right (bool) – Not used in this implementation.

  • start_times – The list of times at which a DisturbanceSource is activated.

  • stop_times (list[int]) – The list of times at which a DisturbanceSource is deactivated.

  • enabled – A parameter which determines whether or not a DisturbanceSource is active.

  • sensor_indices (list[int]) – The indices of the sensors, in the robot’s sensor list, which will be disturbed.

reset() → None[source]

Reset DisturbanceSource by resetting its timer, enabled state and start/stop time lists, as well as its noise source.

step(dt: float) → None[source]

Step MovingSensorsDisturbanceSource forwards in time. The sensors specified in sensor_indices will be moved by a random amount whenever the disturbance source is enabled.

Parameters:

dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the disturbance source over.

SensoryInversionDisturbanceSource class

class Sandbox_V1_4.SensoryInversionDisturbanceSource(robot: Robot, start_times: List[int], sensor_indices: List[int] = [3, 4])[source]

A disturbance source class for switching the positions of two of a Robot’s sensors.

An example of how this will often be used is in a Robot with two LightSensor s, like Braitenberg’s light-seeking and light-avoiding vehicles. Braitenberg’s aggressor (light-seeker) can be turned into his coward (light-avoider) simply by changing its sensorimotor connections from crossed to direct. Keeping the connections the same and swapping the positions of the sensors has the same effect.

For a Robot with more than two sensors, this disturbance source can be used with any pair, specified by sensor_indices when the SensoryInversionDisturbanceSource is constructed.

__init__(robot, start_times, sensor_indices=[0, 1])[source]
Parameters:

  • robot (Robot) – The Robot which will be disturbed.

  • start_times – The list of times at which a DisturbanceSource is activated.

  • sensor_indices (list[int]) – The indices of the two sensors which will have their positions switched. Defaults to [3,4], which are often the indices of the first two light sensors on a Robot.

reset() → None[source]

Reset DisturbanceSource by resetting its timer, enabled state and start/stop time lists, as well as robot sensor angles.

step(dt: float) → None[source]

Step SensoryInversionDisturbanceSource forwards in time. When the disturbance source becomes enabled, the sensors will be switched, and then the disturbance source will immediately be disabled again.

Parameters:

dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the disturbance source over.

LightSwitcherDisturbanceSource class

class Sandbox_V1_4.LightSwitcherDisturbanceSource(light_sources: List[LightSource], start_times: List[int], switch_colours: List[str] = ['red', 'yellow'])[source]

A disturbance source class for switching the colours of lights from red to yellow, and vice versa.

The light sources which will be disturbed should have both of their colour and label parameters set to either ‘red’ or ‘yellow’.

__init__(light_sources: List[LightSource], start_times: List[int], switch_colours: List[str] = ['red', 'yellow'])[source]
Parameters:

  • light_sources (list[LightSource]) – The list of light sources which will be disturbed.

  • start_times – The list of times at which a DisturbanceSource is activated.

  • switch_colours (list[str]) – The two colours which the light sources will be switched between.

reset() → None[source]

Reset DisturbanceSource by resetting its timer, enabled state and start/stop time lists, as well as restoring lights to their riginal states.

step(dt: float) → None[source]

Step LightSwitcherDisturbanceSource forwards in time. When the disturbance source becomes enabled, the lights will be switched, and then the disturbance source will imeediately be disabled again.

Parameters:

dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the disturbance source over.

ParameterDisturbanceSource class

class Sandbox_V1_4.ParameterDisturbanceSource(controller: Controller, start_times: List[int], enabled: bool = True)[source]

A subclass of DisturbanceSource which disturbs the parameters of a Controller, moving them by some random distance in every simulation step when the disturbance is active. This is a one-shot disturbance, so it is triggered for every point of time specified in start_times, but always disabled immediately thereafter.

__init__(controller: Controller, start_times: List[int], enabled: bool = True)[source]
Parameters:

  • controller (Controller) – The Controller to be disturbed.

  • start_times – The list of times at which the DisturbanceSource is activated.

  • stop_times (list[int]) – The list of times at which the DisturbanceSource is deactivated.

  • enabled – The parameter which determines whether or not the DisturbanceSource is active.

reset() → None[source]

Reset disturbance, so it can be re-used in later simulations.

step(dt) → None[source]

Step ParameterDisturbanceSource forwards in time. The disturbed controller’s parameters will be disturbed by a random amount, drawn from a uniform distirbution on the interval [-2, 2], whenever the disturbance source is enabled.

Parameters:

dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the disturbance source over.

MotorNoiseDisturbanceSource class

class Sandbox_V1_4.MotorNoiseDisturbanceSource(motor, white_noise_params: List[float] = [0.0, 0.0], brown_noise_step: float = 0, spike_noise_params: List[float] = [0.0, 0.0, 0.0], start_times=[], stop_times=[], enabled=False)[source]

A class for applying a noise signal generated by a NoiseMaker to the speed of a Motor.

__init__(self, motor, white_noise_params: List[float] = [0.0, 0.0], brown_noise_step: float = 0, spike_noise_params: List[float] = [0.0, 0.0, 0.0], start_times=[], stop_times=[], enabled=False)[source]
Parameters:

  • motor (Motor) – The Motor to be disturbed.

  • white_noise_params (list[float]) – Parameters for the WhiteNoiseSource component of the NoiseMaker.

  • spike_noise_params (list[float]) – Parameters for the SpikeNoiseSource component of the NoiseMaker.

  • brown_noise_step – The maximum amount by which the BrownNoiseSource component of the NoiseMaker can move in each step.

  • start_times – The list of times at which the DisturbanceSource is activated.

  • stop_times (list[int]) – The list of times at which the DisturbanceSource is deactivated.

  • enabled – The parameter which determines whether or not the DisturbanceSource is active.

reset() → None[source]

Reset disturbance, so it can be re-used in later simulations.

step(dt)[source]

Step MotorNoiseDisturbanceSource forwards in time. The disturbed motor’s speed will be disturbed by adding noise whenever the disturbance source is enabled.

Parameters:

dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the disturbance source over.

PathDisturbanceSource class

class Sandbox_V1_4.PathDisturbanceSource(light_sources: List[LightSource], start_times: List[int], stop_times: List[int], n_points: int, enabled=False, d=0.1)[source]

A disturbance source class for disturbing a closed path of lights. While the disturbance is active, the path will be gradually deformed.

__init__(self, light_sources: List[LightSource], start_times: List[int], stop_times: List[int], n_points: int, enabled=False, d=0.1)[source]
Parameters:

  • light_sources (list[LightSource]) – The list of light sources which will be disturbed.

  • start_times – The list of times at which a DisturbanceSource is activated.

  • stop_times (list[int]) – The list of times at which a DisturbanceSource is deactivated.

  • enabled – A parameter which determines whether or not a DisturbanceSource is active.

  • d (float) – A parameter which affects (nonlinearly) how much a path can be disturbed. Defaults to 0.1.

  • n_points (int) – The number of control points which will initially be moved when the path is deformed.

step(dt: float) → None[source]

Step PathDisturbanceSource forwards in time. When the disturbance source becomes enabled, the path of lights will be repeatedly deformed (and gradually, as long as the d parameter is small enough).

Parameters:

dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the disturbance source over.
